item.title: ZeniMax Online Studios founder Matt Firor to depart amid Xbox layoffs
item.content:encoded:
Diego Argüello, Contributing Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

July 3, 2025

2 Min Read

Image via ZeniMax Online Studios

ZeniMax Online Studios founder and Matt Firor, who has led the development of The Elder Scrolls Online (ESO), is departing the company.

Firor shared the news in a statement on X (previously known as Twitter) and explained he will exit "later this month." Following his departure, the studio will be led by Jo Burba as studio head, Susan Kath as executive producer, and Rich Lambert as game director.

"Together, this leadership team has spearheaded many of ESO's biggest ideas and expansions and will continue to make this game something we're all proud of," Firor wrote. "While I won't be working on the game anymore, I will be cheering you on and adding to the thousands of hours I've already spent in-game."

Firor didn't explain why he is departing the studio he established in 2007. It will, however, be a notable loss for the company and owner Microsoft, with Firor having spent almost two decades turning ZeniMax Online Studios into what he describes on Linkedin as a "world-class online game development studio."

The news comes shortly after Microsoft commenced its latest round of layoffs at Xbox with an undisclosed number of job cuts. The layoffs have reportedly impacted several projects across Xbox's roster of internal studios. As noted by Bloomberg reporter Jason Schreier, the cuts also impacted an MMORPG that had been in development at ZeniMax Online Studios since 2018.

Related:Report: Testronic to shutter outsourcing studio Secret 6 Madrid

Last year, ZeniMax Online Studios announced that Elder Scrolls Online would be pivoting from annual expansions to a seasonal model. As Firor wrote at the time, seasons are expected to run for "three or six months," and the move from yearly expansions is designed to make life easier for the studio. The announcement took place mere days after 461 employees at the studio formed a union to deliver "protections against layoffs and workplace exploitation."

It remains unclear how many workers at ZeniMax Online Studios have been laid off by Microsoft.

About the Author

Video games helped him to learn English, so now he covers them for places like The New York Times, NPR, Rolling Stone, and more. item.title: Report: Testronic to shutter outsourcing studio Secret 6 Madrid
item.content:encoded:
Chris Kerr, Senior Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

July 8, 2025

2 Min Read

Game service provider Testronic reportedly intends to shutter Secret 6 Madrid and make at least 42 employees redundant.

The game development and art studio has offices in both Manila and Madrid, but it seems the latter has now been placed on the chopping block less than three years after it was purchased by Testronic and parent company Catalis Group.

The Spanish outfit has worked on notable titles including Diablo IV, The Last of Us: Part II—Remastered, Lords of the Fallen, PGA Tour, Madden NFL, and Silent Hill: Ascension.

Multiple employees announced the closure on Linkedin and suggested the decision was made without warning or reason. Secret 6 Madrid lead game producer Patricia Menéndez said the studio will potentially wind down on July 31, 2025, and placed the blame at the door of corporate leadership.

She said the team's efforts to fight back have so far been unsuccessful.

"If confirmed, the closure would affect 42 people: an exceptional team of 2D, 3D, and VFX artists specialising in AAA video games, as well as professionals in production and human resources," she added.

"We face this situation with deep sadness at the injustice it represents, but also with the strong conviction that this team is made up of brilliant professionals: people with talent, commitment, and an immense passion for their work, who will continue to fight to the very end to keep doing what they do best."

Related:Update: Romero Games in talks with new publishers after Microsoft reportedly cancels project funding

Others corroborated those reports, including lead 3D artist Angel Blanco and art manager Adrián Sanz Cárcamo.

Cárcamo again stated the situation was communicated to employees without any prior warning or solid rationale.

"Our Madrid local management team had no idea and was equally astonished," he wrote in a scathing LinkedIn post. "Testronic, a subsidiary of Catalis group, acquired our company, Secret 6, in the last quarter of 2022. And since then, they have done nothing. They watched us in the most absolute of silences—and they let us die."

Secret 6 was sharing job listings on Linkedin less than a week ago. It's unclear whether Secret 6 Manila is also facing cuts.

Game Developer has reached out to Testronic for comment.
